advice.pattern: Network Adapter could not establish the connection|Communications link failure|Connection timed out|Socket fail to connect
advice.message:
Press 'Learn How to Connect' button in the previous dialog to verify the basic requirements. Then check:

» Firewalls or antivirus may block the port.
» Database to be started. Check the MariaDb Service to run.
» The database user, password and port should be the same as configured during installation.
» Try to replace localhost with 127.0.0.1

advice.pattern: Network Adapter could not establish the connection|Communications link failure|Connection timed out
advice.message:
» Enable remote access in MySql Server.
» For cloud databases, ensure the database is public accessible and the security group includes your IP
» Press the Ping button
» Make sure the Firewall does not block the communication. This could be set during installation or add a inbound rule.
Check the host field. The host should be registered with DNS servers. Try to ping it from the Connection Dialog. Check the help for details.

The user 'root' is not allowed to connect from another machine (only from the localhost).
For remote connections create a dedicated user in MariaDb Command Line:
CREATE USER 'dbschema'@'%' IDENTIFIED BY 'password';
GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES ON *.* TO 'dbschema'@'%' WITH GRANT OPTION;
FLUSH PRIVILEGES;

advice.pattern: is not allowed to connect|Connection refused|Access denied for user
advice.message:
Enable remote connections in MariaDb server. Press 'Help' for details.
In MariaDb Command Line, do 'SELECT user, host FROM information_schema.users' and ensure the host is '%' or the current host name.
Check the password.

The URL driver requires some parameters so MariaDb will handle empty dates in a proper way.
Change the URL in the JDBC driver manager to :
jdbc:mariadb://<HOST>:3306/<DB>?useUnicode=true&characterEncoding=UTF8&zeroDateTimeBehavior=convertToNull

advice.pattern: Cannot add or update a child row: a foreign key constraint fails
advice.message:
The existing table data is violating the foreign key condition.
Please check that referencing column data exist in the primary key column.

advice.pattern: Data truncated for column|Invalid use of NULL value
advice.message:
Is possible that some column records contains empty ( NULL ) values.
You can use Relational Data Editor to list and edit them ( use a IS EMPTY filter on that column ). From SQL Editor you can execute "SELECT col FROM table WHERE col IS NULL" and "UPDATE table SET col='value' WHERE col IS NULL".

advice.pattern: can be only one auto column and it must be defined as a key
advice.message:
Autoincrement columns values are generated by database ( 1,2,3...) for each inserted dataRecord.
One table may have maximal one autoincrement column.
Is expected that the autoincrement column is also Primary Key.
This means it will unique identify each table dataRecord.

Please check:
  • Columns have the same data type
  • Referred column is primary key or mandatory with an unique index

The Primary Key or Unique Indexes cannot contain a value two times. Same for unique indexes.
Check if the value already exist.

Grant privileges executing 'GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES ON *.* TO 'root'@'localhost' IDENTIFIED BY '%password%' WITH GRANT OPTION; FLUSH PRIVILEGES;' from MySql console.
Check the Help for understanding the username and host.
The database user is now allowed to write in the database. Give the user write rights or login using a different user.
Foreign key error. Check that the referencing and referred columns have the same type and the fk name is not used by another fk or index.
